item.title: Camping in Peru
item.dc:creator: techteam
item.content:encoded:
Camping is an outdoor activity involving overnight stays away from home in a shelter, such as a tent, a caravan, or a motorhome. Generally participants leave developed areas to spend time outdoors in more natural ones in pursuit of activities providing them enjoyment. To be regarded as "camping" a minimum of one night is spent outdoors, distinguishing it from day-tripping, picnicking, and other similarly short-term recreational activities. Camping can be enjoyed through all four seasons.

Luxury may be an element, as in early 20th century African safaris, but including accommodations in fully equipped fixed structures such as high-end sporting camps under the banner of "camping" blurs the line.

Camping as a recreational activity became popular among elites in the early 20th century. With time, it grew more democratic, and varied. Modern campers frequent publicly owned natural resources such as national and state parks, wilderness areas, and commercial campgrounds. Camping is a key part of many youth organizations around the world, such as Scouting, which use it to teach both self-reliance and teamwork.

Camping describes a range of activities and approaches to outdoor accommodation. Survivalist campers set off with as little as possible to get by, whereas recreational vehicle travelers arrive equipped with their own electricity, heat, and patio furniture. Camping may be combined with hiking, as in backpacking, and is often enjoyed in conjunction with other outdoor activities such as canoeing, climbing, fishing, and hunting.

There is no universally held definition of what is and what is not camping. Fundamentally, it reflects a combination of intent and the nature of activities involved. A children's summer camp with dining hall meals and bunkhouse accommodations may have "camp" in its name but fails to reflect the spirit and form of "camping" as it is broadly understood. Similarly, a homeless person's lifestyle may involve many common camping activities, such as sleeping out and preparing meals over a fire, but fails to reflect the elective nature and pursuit of spirit rejuvenation that are integral aspect of camping. Likewise, cultures with itinerant lifestyles or lack of permanent dwellings cannot be said to be "camping", it is just their way of life.

item.title: Skydiving from Mt. Everest
item.dc:creator: techteam
item.content:encoded:
There is no universally held definition of what is and what is not camping. Fundamentally, it reflects a combination of intent and the nature of activities involved. A children's summer camp with dining hall meals and bunkhouse accommodations may have "camp" in its name but fails to reflect the spirit and form of "camping" as it is broadly understood. Similarly, a homeless person's lifestyle may involve many common camping activities, such as sleeping out and preparing meals over a fire, but fails to reflect the elective nature and pursuit of spirit rejuvenation that are integral aspect of camping. Likewise, cultures with itinerant lifestyles or lack of permanent dwellings cannot be said to be "camping", it is just their way of life..

Luxury may be an element, as in early 20th century African safaris, but including accommodations in fully equipped fixed structures such as high-end sporting camps under the banner of "camping" blurs the line.

Camping is an outdoor activity involving overnight stays away from home in a shelter, such as a tent, a caravan, or a motorhome. Generally participants leave developed areas to spend time outdoors in more natural ones in pursuit of activities providing them enjoyment. To be regarded as "camping" a minimum of one night is spent outdoors, distinguishing it from day-tripping, picnicking, and other similarly short-term recreational activities. Camping can be enjoyed through all four seasons.

Camping as a recreational activity became popular among elites in the early 20th century. With time, it grew more democratic, and varied. Modern campers frequent publicly owned natural resources such as national and state parks, wilderness areas, and commercial campgrounds. Camping is a key part of many youth organizations around the world, such as Scouting, which use it to teach both self-reliance and teamwork.

Camping describes a range of activities and approaches to outdoor accommodation. Survivalist campers set off with as little as possible to get by, whereas recreational vehicle travelers arrive equipped with their own electricity, heat, and patio furniture. Camping may be combined with hiking, as in backpacking, and is often enjoyed in conjunction with other outdoor activities such as canoeing, climbing, fishing, and hunting.

item.title: Exploring Untravelled Destinations
item.dc:creator: techteam
item.content:encoded:
Exploration is the act of searching for the purpose of discovery of information or resources. Exploration occurs in all non-sessile animal species, including humans. In human history, its most dramatic rise was during the Age of Discovery when European explorers sailed and charted much of the rest of the world for a variety of reasons. Since then, major explorations after the Age of Discovery have occurred for reasons mostly aimed at information discovery.

In scientific research, exploration is one of three purposes of empirical research (the other two being description and explanation). The term is commonly used metaphorically. For example, an individual may speak of exploring the Internet, sexuality, etc.

The Phoenicians (1550 BCE–300 BCE) traded throughout the Mediterranean Sea and Asia Minor though many of their routes are still unknown today. The presence of tin in some Phoenician artifacts suggests that they may have traveled to Britain. According to Virgil's Aeneid and other ancient sources, the legendary Queen Dido was a Phoenician from Tyre who sailed to North Africa and founded the city of Carthage.

During the 2nd century BC, the Han dynasty explored much of the Eastern Northern Hemisphere. Starting in 139 BC, the Han diplomat Zhang Qian traveled west in an unsuccessful attempt to secure an alliance with the Da Yuezhi against the Xiongnu (the Yuezhi had been evicted from Gansu by the Xiongnu in 177 BC); however, Zhang's travels discovered entire countries which the Chinese were unaware of, including the remnants of the conquests of Alexander the Great (r. 336–323 BC).When Zhang returned to China in 125 BC, he reported on his visits to Dayuan (Fergana), Kangju (Sogdiana), and Daxia (Bactria, formerly the Greco-Bactrian Kingdom which had just been subjugated by the Da Yuezhi). Zhang described Dayuan and Daxia as agricultural and urban countries like China, and although he did not venture there, described Shendu (the Indus River valley of Northwestern India) and Anxi (Arsacid territories) further west.

item.title: Mountain Climbing in the Himalayas
item.dc:creator: techteam
item.content:encoded:
The term mountaineering describes the sport of mountain climbing. While some scholars identify mountaineering-related activities as climbing (rock and ice) and trekking up mountains,others are also adding backpacking, hiking, skiing, via ferrata and wilderness activities,and still others state that mountaineering activities also include indoor climbing, sport climbing and bouldering.However most of the scholars, the term mountaineering understand as a climbing (which now refers to adventure climbing or sports climbing) and trekking (hill walking in 'exotic' places). Hiking in the mountains can also be a simple form of mountaineering when it involves scrambling, or short stretches of the more basic grades of rock climbing, as well as crossing glaciers.

While mountaineering began as attempts to reach the highest point of unclimbed big mountains it has branched into specializations that address different aspects of the mountain and consists of three areas: rock-craft, snow-craft, and skiing, depending on whether the route chosen is over rock, snow or ice. All require experience, athletic ability, and technical knowledge to maintain safety.

Mountaineering is often called Alpinism, especially in European languages, which implies climbing routes with minimal equipment in high and often snow and ice-covered mountains such as the Alps, where technical difficulties frequently exceed environmental and physical challenges. A mountaineer who pursues this more technical and minimalist style of mountain climbing is sometimes called an Alpinist, although use of the term may vary between countries and eras. The word "alpinism" was born in the 19th century to refer to climbing for the purpose of enjoying climbing itself as a sport or recreation, distinct from merely climbing while hunting or as a religious pilgrimage that had been done generally at that time.

The UIAA or Union Internationale des Associations d'Alpinisme is the world governing body in mountaineering and climbing, addressing issues like access, medical, mountain protection, safety, youth and ice climbing.

Historically, many cultures have harbored superstitions about mountains, which they often regarded as sacred due to their perceived proximity with heaven, such as Mount Olympus for the Ancient Greeks.

On April 26, 1336 famous Italian poet Petrarch climbed to the summit of 1,912m Mount Ventoux overlooking the Bay of Marseilles, claiming to be inspired by Philip V of Macedon's ascent of Mount Haemo, making him the first known alpinist.

One of the first European mountains visited by many tourists was Sněžka. This was mainly due to the relatively minor technical difficulties ascent and the fact that since the sixteenth century, many resort visitors flocked to the nearby Cieplice Śląskie-Zdrój and highly visible Sněžka, visually dominant over all Krkonoše was for them an important attraction. The first confirmed ascent took place in the year 1456.

In 1492 Antoine de Ville, lord of Domjulien and Beaupré, was the first to ascend the Mont Aiguille, in France, with a little team, using ladders and ropes. It appears to be the first recorded climb of any technical difficulty, and has been said to mark the beginning of mountaineering.

In 1573 Francesco De Marchi and Francesco Di Domenico ascended Corno Grande, the highest peak in the Apennine Mountains. During the Enlightenment, as a product of the new spirit of curiosity for the natural world, many mountain summits were surmounted for the first time.

item.title: Eiffel Tower, Paris
item.dc:creator: techteam
item.content:encoded:
The Annapurna Circuit is a trek within the Annapurna mountain range of central Nepal.The total length of the route varies between 160–230 km (100-145 mi), depending on where motor transportation is used and where the trek is ended. This trek crosses two different river valleys and encircles the Annapurna massif. The path reaches its highest point at Thorung La pass (5416m/17769 ft), touching the edge of the Tibetan plateau.

Practically all trekkers hike the route anticlockwise, as this way the daily altitude gain is slower, and crossing the high Thorong La pass is easier and safer. The mountain scenery, seen at close quarters includes the Annapurna Massif (Annapurna I-IV), Dhaulagiri, Machhapuchhre, Manaslu, Gangapurna, Tilicho Peak, Pisang Peak, and Paungda Danda. Numerous other peaks of 6000-8000m in elevation rise from the Annapurna range. The trek begins at Besisahar or Bhulbhule in the Marshyangdi river valley and concludes in the Kali Gandaki Gorge. Besisahar can be reached after a seven-hour drive from Kathmandu.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
a:7:{s:9:"trip_code";s:7:"WTE-261";s:13:"trip_duration";i:15;s:20:"trip_duration_nights";i:14;s:11:"tab_content";a:1:{s:10:"1_wpeditor";s:1268:"

Travel is the movement of people between relatively distant geographical locations, and can involve travel by foot, bicycle, automobile, train, boat, bus, airplane, or other means, with or without luggage, and can be one way or round trip. Travel can also include relatively short stays between successive movements.

The origin of the word "travel" is most likely lost to history. The term "travel" may originate from the Old French word travail, which means 'work'. According to the Merriam Webster dictionary, the first known use of the word travel was in the 14th century.

It also states that the word comes from Middle English travailen, travelen (which means to torment, labor, strive, journey) and earlier from Old French travailler (which means to work strenuously, toil). In English we still occasionally use the words "travail", which means struggle. According to Simon Winchester in his book The Best Travelers' Tales (2004), the words "travel" and "travail" both share an even more ancient root: a Roman instrument of torture called the tripalium (in Latin it means "three stakes", as in to impale).

";}s:9:"itinerary";a:3:{s:15:"itinerary_title";a:4:{i:1;s:33:"Arrival and Introduction to Paris";i:2;s:52:"Eiffel Tower Climbing Experience and Paris Landmarks";i:3;s:50:"Eiffel Tower at Sunrise and Montmartre Exploration";i:4;s:41:"Eiffel Tower Visit and Seine River Cruise";}s:20:"itinerary_days_label";a:4:{i:1;s:6:"Day 01";i:2;s:6:"Day 02";i:3;s:6:"Day 03";i:4;s:6:"Day 04";}s:17:"itinerary_content";a:4:{i:1;s:654:"

Arrive in Paris and check into your accommodation, where you’ll have the rest of the day to rest and settle in. In the late afternoon, take a leisurely walk along the Seine River, soaking in the iconic views of the city’s historic bridges and landmarks. In the evening, enjoy a traditional French dinner in a charming Parisian bistro. Afterward, head to the Eiffel Tower for a stunning nighttime visit. Ascend to the observation decks to witness the breathtaking panorama of Paris lit up under the stars. The Eiffel Tower’s sparkling lights will give you a truly magical introduction to the city.

";i:2;s:693:"

Start your day early with a guided climb up the Eiffel Tower. Skip the elevator and enjoy the challenge of climbing the 674 steps to the second level, where you can take in a bird’s-eye view of Paris. Once on the observation deck, learn about the history of the tower and its significance in Parisian culture. Afterward, descend and enjoy a relaxing lunch at one of the local cafés, then explore the nearby Trocadéro Gardens for more photo opportunities. In the afternoon, visit the Champs-Élysées, Arc de Triomphe, and other famous Parisian landmarks to deepen your understanding of the city’s rich history and architectural beauty.

";i:3;s:734:"

Rise early for a quiet sunrise visit to the Eiffel Tower, where you can experience the city coming to life from one of the world’s most famous landmarks. The tranquility of the early morning offers a more peaceful perspective before the crowds arrive. Afterward, enjoy a delicious French breakfast at a nearby café. Spend the rest of the morning exploring Montmartre, the bohemian district where artists like Picasso and Van Gogh once lived. Wander through its charming streets, visit the Sacré-Cœur Basilica, and take in the stunning views of Paris from the hilltop. In the evening, attend a classic French cabaret show at the Moulin Rouge or another iconic venue in the area.

";i:4;s:597:"

On your final day in Paris, take one last visit to the Eiffel Tower, either by climbing again for a more relaxed experience or taking the elevator to the top for panoramic views of the city. Afterward, spend the afternoon enjoying a scenic Seine River cruise, passing by many of the city’s most famous landmarks, including Notre-Dame, the Louvre, and the Musée d’Orsay. In the evening, enjoy a farewell dinner at a restaurant with a view of the Eiffel Tower, watching as it illuminates the Paris skyline one last time before your departure.

";}}s:4:"cost";a:4:{s:14:"includes_title";s:22:"The Trip Cost Includes";s:13:"cost_includes";s:704:"Pick-up or Drop-off service from and to Airport(in our own vehicle) Transportation to and from!! Food all along the trip(Breakfast, Lunch, Dinner and a cup of coffee or tea) and accommodations during the trip in hotels with family environment Transportation, food, accommodation and insurance of Guide during the trip Down jacket, all-season sleeping bag, duffel bag and trekking map(in case if you don’t have your own. Down jacket, sleeping bag and duffel bag must be returned after completion of the trip) First Aid Medical Kit(Your guide will carry the Medical Kit but we also advise to bring yourself for your own use, as far as possible) All the required permits and paperwork";s:14:"excludes_title";s:22:"The Trip Cost Excludes";s:13:"cost_excludes";s:417:"International Airfare Visa Charges Hotel Expenses(In Kathmandu, some packages do include hotel expenses) Your travel and medical insurance Personal Expenses such as shopping, bar bills, hot shower, telephone, laundry, titbits etc Food and accommodations in Kathmandu Services not mentioned or not promised by the agent/agency Emergency expenses such as expenses on chartered helicopter.";}s:3:"faq";a:2:{s:9:"faq_title";a:4:{i:0;s:71:"What is the best time of day to visit the Eiffel Tower during the tour?";i:1;s:64:"Do I need to book tickets in advance for the Eiffel Tower climb?";i:2;s:70:"Are there any age or physical restrictions for the Eiffel Tower climb?";i:3;s:60:"Is there any guided commentary during the Eiffel Tower tour?";}s:11:"faq_content";a:4:{i:0;s:442:"

The best time to visit the Eiffel Tower is early in the morning or late in the afternoon. Visiting in the morning allows you to avoid the crowds and enjoy a peaceful ascent to the observation decks. If you're interested in seeing the Eiffel Tower illuminated at night, an evening visit is ideal, as the tower lights up every hour after sunset, offering a magical view of Paris from the top.

";i:1;s:444:"

It is highly recommended to book tickets in advance, especially if you are planning to climb the Eiffel Tower. Pre-booking allows you to skip the long lines at the ticket counters and ensures you have a reserved time slot. If you opt for the climb instead of the elevator, there are limited spots, and advance reservations can help secure your spot for a more enjoyable and timely experience.

";i:2;s:509:"

The climb up the Eiffel Tower is physically demanding, with 674 steps to the second level. While there are no specific age restrictions, it is recommended for those who are in good health and physically capable of climbing the stairs. For those with limited mobility or young children, the elevator option may be more suitable. The tour guides can also offer assistance and provide alternative routes for participants who prefer a less strenuous experience.

";i:3;s:510:"

Yes, during the Eiffel Tower tour, a knowledgeable guide will provide commentary, offering fascinating insights into the tower’s history, construction, and cultural significance. You'll learn about the tower’s role in shaping the Paris skyline and its evolution from a temporary exhibition piece to a permanent symbol of the city. The guide will also point out key landmarks visible from the observation decks, enriching your overall experience of Paris.

";}}}

The best time to visit the Eiffel Tower is early in the morning or late in the afternoon. Visiting in the morning allows you to avoid the crowds and enjoy a peaceful ascent to the observation decks. If you're interested in seeing the Eiffel Tower illuminated at night, an evening visit is ideal, as the tower lights up every hour after sunset, offering a magical view of Paris from the top.

";i:1;s:444:"

It is highly recommended to book tickets in advance, especially if you are planning to climb the Eiffel Tower. Pre-booking allows you to skip the long lines at the ticket counters and ensures you have a reserved time slot. If you opt for the climb instead of the elevator, there are limited spots, and advance reservations can help secure your spot for a more enjoyable and timely experience.

";i:2;s:509:"

The climb up the Eiffel Tower is physically demanding, with 674 steps to the second level. While there are no specific age restrictions, it is recommended for those who are in good health and physically capable of climbing the stairs. For those with limited mobility or young children, the elevator option may be more suitable. The tour guides can also offer assistance and provide alternative routes for participants who prefer a less strenuous experience.

";i:3;s:510:"

Yes, during the Eiffel Tower tour, a knowledgeable guide will provide commentary, offering fascinating insights into the tower’s history, construction, and cultural significance. You'll learn about the tower’s role in shaping the Paris skyline and its evolution from a temporary exhibition piece to a permanent symbol of the city. The guide will also point out key landmarks visible from the observation decks, enriching your overall experience of Paris.

";}}}

item.title: Colosseum, Rome, Italy
item.dc:creator: techteam
item.content:encoded:
The Annapurna Circuit is a trek within the Annapurna mountain range of central Nepal.The total length of the route varies between 160–230 km (100-145 mi), depending on where motor transportation is used and where the trek is ended. This trek crosses two different river valleys and encircles the Annapurna massif. The path reaches its highest point at Thorung La pass (5416m/17769 ft), touching the edge of the Tibetan plateau.

Practically all trekkers hike the route anticlockwise, as this way the daily altitude gain is slower, and crossing the high Thorong La pass is easier and safer. The mountain scenery, seen at close quarters includes the Annapurna Massif (Annapurna I-IV), Dhaulagiri, Machhapuchhre, Manaslu, Gangapurna, Tilicho Peak, Pisang Peak, and Paungda Danda. Numerous other peaks of 6000-8000m in elevation rise from the Annapurna range. The trek begins at Besisahar or Bhulbhule in the Marshyangdi river valley and concludes in the Kali Gandaki Gorge. Besisahar can be reached after a seven-hour drive from Kathmandu.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
a:7:{s:9:"trip_code";s:7:"WTE-262";s:13:"trip_duration";i:15;s:20:"trip_duration_nights";i:14;s:11:"tab_content";a:1:{s:10:"1_wpeditor";s:1268:"

Travel is the movement of people between relatively distant geographical locations, and can involve travel by foot, bicycle, automobile, train, boat, bus, airplane, or other means, with or without luggage, and can be one way or round trip. Travel can also include relatively short stays between successive movements.

The origin of the word "travel" is most likely lost to history. The term "travel" may originate from the Old French word travail, which means 'work'. According to the Merriam Webster dictionary, the first known use of the word travel was in the 14th century.

It also states that the word comes from Middle English travailen, travelen (which means to torment, labor, strive, journey) and earlier from Old French travailler (which means to work strenuously, toil). In English we still occasionally use the words "travail", which means struggle. According to Simon Winchester in his book The Best Travelers' Tales (2004), the words "travel" and "travail" both share an even more ancient root: a Roman instrument of torture called the tripalium (in Latin it means "three stakes", as in to impale).

";}s:9:"itinerary";a:3:{s:15:"itinerary_title";a:4:{i:1;s:40:"Arrival and Introduction to Ancient Rome";i:2;s:37:"Colosseum Exploration and Roman Forum";i:3;s:36:"Palatine Hill and Capitoline Museums";i:4;s:34:"Colosseum Underground and Farewell";}s:20:"itinerary_days_label";a:4:{i:1;s:6:"Day 01";i:2;s:6:"Day 02";i:3;s:6:"Day 03";i:4;s:6:"Day 04";}s:17:"itinerary_content";a:4:{i:1;s:599:"

Arrive in Rome and check into your accommodation, where you'll have the rest of the day to relax after your journey. In the late afternoon, head out for a leisurely walk through the historic center, getting a first glimpse of iconic landmarks like the Roman Forum and the Pantheon. As the evening sets in, enjoy a delicious Italian dinner in a traditional trattoria, and get a taste of Roman cuisine. After dinner, take a short walk around Piazza del Colosseo to see the Colosseum illuminated, providing a perfect preview of the adventure to come.

";i:2;s:742:"

After breakfast, begin your day with a guided tour of the Colosseum, one of the most famous landmarks in the world. Skip the long lines with your reserved entry and explore the amphitheater, learning about its history as the center of gladiatorial combat and public spectacles. The guide will provide rich details about the Colosseum’s architecture, construction, and its role in ancient Roman society. Afterward, head to the nearby Roman Forum, where you’ll stroll through the ruins of ancient government buildings, temples, and markets, gaining insight into the daily life of ancient Romans. The evening is free to explore more of Rome or enjoy a relaxed dinner at a local restaurant.

";i:3;s:622:"

Begin your day with a visit to Palatine Hill, the legendary birthplace of Rome, offering breathtaking views of the city and the Roman Forum below. Explore the ancient palaces and gardens, learning about the emperors who once lived there. In the afternoon, visit the Capitoline Museums, home to a vast collection of Roman art, sculptures, and ancient artifacts. Here, you’ll deepen your understanding of Roman culture and history. Afterward, spend the evening at leisure, perhaps enjoying a walk to the Trevi Fountain or Piazza Navona, both beautifully lit up at night.

";i:4;s:658:"

On your final day, embark on an exclusive underground tour of the Colosseum, exploring areas that are usually off-limits to the public. This tour takes you beneath the arena floor to the passageways where gladiators and animals waited before their matches, giving you a unique perspective on the ancient structure. After the tour, take some time to explore the Colosseum’s upper levels for panoramic views of the surrounding city. In the afternoon, enjoy a final leisurely walk around Rome’s charming streets, and perhaps grab a last Italian meal before heading to the airport or your next destination.

";}}s:4:"cost";a:4:{s:14:"includes_title";s:22:"The Trip Cost Includes";s:13:"cost_includes";s:704:"Pick-up or Drop-off service from and to Airport(in our own vehicle) Transportation to and from!! Food all along the trip(Breakfast, Lunch, Dinner and a cup of coffee or tea) and accommodations during the trip in hotels with family environment Transportation, food, accommodation and insurance of Guide during the trip Down jacket, all-season sleeping bag, duffel bag and trekking map(in case if you don’t have your own. Down jacket, sleeping bag and duffel bag must be returned after completion of the trip) First Aid Medical Kit(Your guide will carry the Medical Kit but we also advise to bring yourself for your own use, as far as possible) All the required permits and paperwork";s:14:"excludes_title";s:22:"The Trip Cost Excludes";s:13:"cost_excludes";s:417:"International Airfare Visa Charges Hotel Expenses(In Kathmandu, some packages do include hotel expenses) Your travel and medical insurance Personal Expenses such as shopping, bar bills, hot shower, telephone, laundry, titbits etc Food and accommodations in Kathmandu Services not mentioned or not promised by the agent/agency Emergency expenses such as expenses on chartered helicopter.";}s:3:"faq";a:2:{s:9:"faq_title";a:4:{i:0;s:58:"What is the best way to avoid long lines at the Colosseum?";i:1;s:70:"Is it possible to visit the Colosseum underground or restricted areas?";i:2;s:48:"How long does the Colosseum tour typically last?";i:3;s:70:"Are there any age or mobility restrictions for visiting the Colosseum?";}s:11:"faq_content";a:4:{i:0;s:386:"

The best way to avoid long lines is to book a skip-the-line ticket or a guided tour in advance. These options allow you to bypass the often long queues at the ticket counter, giving you faster access to the Colosseum. Many tour companies offer packages that include exclusive entry, ensuring a more efficient and enjoyable experience.

";i:1;s:462:"

Yes, visitors can access the underground and restricted areas of the Colosseum through special guided tours. These tours offer a deeper insight into the structure, including the gladiator chambers, animal holding areas, and the intricate system of tunnels beneath the arena. These tours are limited and must be booked in advance, as access to these areas is typically not included in general admission tickets.

";i:2;s:413:"

The standard guided tour of the Colosseum lasts around 1.5 to 2 hours. This duration includes time to explore the main areas, including the arena floor, upper levels, and often the Roman Forum and Palatine Hill. If you choose to add on an underground tour or explore additional sites, such as the Capitoline Museums, the total tour time can extend to 3-4 hours.

";i:3;s:541:"

The Colosseum is accessible for visitors with limited mobility, though some areas, particularly the upper levels, can be challenging due to uneven surfaces and stairs. However, the main areas of the Colosseum and the arena floor are accessible for wheelchairs, and the site provides services for visitors with disabilities. For families, children are welcome, but strollers may not be allowed in certain areas of the Colosseum, and a baby carrier might be recommended for younger children.

";}}}

item.title: Paragliding is Life
item.dc:creator: techteam
item.content:encoded:
The Annapurna Circuit is a trek within the Annapurna mountain range of central Nepal.The total length of the route varies between 160–230 km (100-145 mi), depending on where motor transportation is used and where the trek is ended. This trek crosses two different river valleys and encircles the Annapurna massif. The path reaches its highest point at Thorung La pass (5416m/17769 ft), touching the edge of the Tibetan plateau.

Practically all trekkers hike the route anticlockwise, as this way the daily altitude gain is slower, and crossing the high Thorong La pass is easier and safer. The mountain scenery, seen at close quarters includes the Annapurna Massif (Annapurna I-IV), Dhaulagiri, Machhapuchhre, Manaslu, Gangapurna, Tilicho Peak, Pisang Peak, and Paungda Danda. Numerous other peaks of 6000-8000m in elevation rise from the Annapurna range. The trek begins at Besisahar or Bhulbhule in the Marshyangdi river valley and concludes in the Kali Gandaki Gorge. Besisahar can be reached after a seven-hour drive from Kathmandu.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
a:7:{s:9:"trip_code";s:7:"WTE-269";s:13:"trip_duration";i:15;s:20:"trip_duration_nights";i:14;s:11:"tab_content";a:1:{s:10:"1_wpeditor";s:1268:"

Travel is the movement of people between relatively distant geographical locations, and can involve travel by foot, bicycle, automobile, train, boat, bus, airplane, or other means, with or without luggage, and can be one way or round trip. Travel can also include relatively short stays between successive movements.

The origin of the word "travel" is most likely lost to history. The term "travel" may originate from the Old French word travail, which means 'work'. According to the Merriam Webster dictionary, the first known use of the word travel was in the 14th century.

It also states that the word comes from Middle English travailen, travelen (which means to torment, labor, strive, journey) and earlier from Old French travailler (which means to work strenuously, toil). In English we still occasionally use the words "travail", which means struggle. According to Simon Winchester in his book The Best Travelers' Tales (2004), the words "travel" and "travail" both share an even more ancient root: a Roman instrument of torture called the tripalium (in Latin it means "three stakes", as in to impale).

";}s:9:"itinerary";a:3:{s:15:"itinerary_title";a:4:{i:1;s:39:"Arrival and Introduction to Paragliding";i:2;s:37:"First Flight and Paragliding Training";i:3;s:50:"Advanced Paragliding Experience and Scenic Flights";i:4;s:27:"Sunrise Flight and Farewell";}s:20:"itinerary_days_label";a:4:{i:1;s:6:"Day 01";i:2;s:6:"Day 02";i:3;s:6:"Day 03";i:4;s:6:"Day 04";}s:17:"itinerary_content";a:4:{i:1;s:593:"

Arrive at your destination, often a picturesque paragliding hub like Pokhara in Nepal, where the stunning views of the Himalayas set the stage for an exciting adventure. After checking into your hotel, you’ll meet your paragliding instructor for a briefing on the equipment, safety measures, and what to expect during the tour. The rest of the day is free to explore the town, soaking in the local culture, enjoying a lakeside stroll, or simply relaxing. In the evening, gather for a welcome dinner and get to know your fellow adventurers.

";i:2;s:636:"

After a hearty breakfast, head to the paragliding launch site, where you'll receive a safety briefing and a short training session. For those new to the sport, you'll have an opportunity for a tandem flight with an experienced instructor, gliding through the air and taking in breathtaking aerial views of mountains, lakes, and villages below. If you're already a seasoned paraglider, you can practice solo flights under the supervision of your instructor. Afterward, enjoy a relaxing afternoon, perhaps visiting local attractions like caves or temples, before a well-deserved dinner.

";i:3;s:620:"

Today, dive deeper into the sport with a series of more advanced flights. Depending on your skill level, you’ll have the opportunity to fly solo or tandem, navigating thermals and exploring new flight routes. Your instructor will guide you through the experience, teaching you the finer points of flight control, maneuvers, and landing techniques. The breathtaking landscapes of the surrounding mountains, valleys, and lakes will serve as the perfect backdrop. In the evening, enjoy a debriefing session to review your progress and discuss any areas for improvement.

";i:4;s:596:"

On your final day, rise early to catch a spectacular sunrise flight. Witness the sun lighting up the snow-capped peaks of the surrounding mountains as you soar high above the landscape. After your early morning adventure, enjoy a relaxed breakfast and a reflective session to share your experiences. The remainder of the day is yours to explore more of the local culture, shop for souvenirs, or simply relax by the lake before your departure. After an exhilarating few days, depart with unforgettable memories and a new passion for paragliding.

Food all along the trip(Breakfast, Lunch, Dinner and a cup of coffee or tea) and accommodations during the trip in hotels with family environment Transportation, food, accommodation and insurance of Guide during the trip Down jacket, all-season sleeping bag, duffel bag and trekking map(in case if you don’t have your own. Down jacket, sleeping bag and duffel bag must be returned after completion of the trip) First Aid Medical Kit(Your guide will carry the Medical Kit but we also advise to bring yourself for your own use, as far as possible) All the required permits and paperwork";s:14:"excludes_title";s:22:"The Trip Cost Excludes";s:13:"cost_excludes";s:417:"International Airfare Visa Charges Hotel Expenses(In Kathmandu, some packages do include hotel expenses) Your travel and medical insurance Personal Expenses such as shopping, bar bills, hot shower, telephone, laundry, titbits etc Food and accommodations in Kathmandu Services not mentioned or not promised by the agent/agency Emergency expenses such as expenses on chartered helicopter.";}s:3:"faq";a:2:{s:9:"faq_title";a:4:{i:0;s:78:"Do I need prior paragliding experience to join the "Paragliding is Life" tour?";i:1;s:66:"What safety measures are in place for paragliding during the tour?";i:2;s:85:"How many people are in a group, and what kind of support is provided during the tour?";i:3;s:69:"Is the paragliding equipment provided, or should I bring my own gear?";}s:11:"faq_content";a:4:{i:0;s:387:"

No prior paragliding experience is required for the tour. If you're a beginner, you will fly tandem with a certified instructor, allowing you to enjoy the experience safely. For those with experience, there will be opportunities to fly solo under the guidance of an instructor, honing your skills and exploring more challenging routes.

";i:1;s:422:"

Safety is our top priority. All flights are conducted with experienced, certified instructors who provide thorough safety briefings and guidance before each flight. We use high-quality, regularly inspected equipment, including harnesses, helmets, and reserve parachutes. Weather conditions are carefully monitored, and flights are only conducted when it's safe to do so.

";i:2;s:413:"

Groups typically consist of 6-10 participants, ensuring a personalized experience with plenty of attention from the instructors. Support is provided by a team of experienced paragliding instructors, ground crew, and local guides who assist with flight preparation, gear handling, and logistics. This ensures that everyone enjoys a safe and memorable experience.

";i:3;s:394:"

All necessary paragliding equipment, including the glider, harness, helmet, and safety gear, is provided for the tour. If you prefer, you can bring your own gear, but it must meet safety standards and be approved by the instructors. If you need any additional items such as gloves, jackets, or shoes, those can be rented or purchased locally.

";}}}

a:7:{s:9:"trip_code";s:7:"WTE-269";s:13:"trip_duration";i:15;s:20:"trip_duration_nights";i:14;s:11:"tab_content";a:1:{s:10:"1_wpeditor";s:1268:"

Travel is the movement of people between relatively distant geographical locations, and can involve travel by foot, bicycle, automobile, train, boat, bus, airplane, or other means, with or without luggage, and can be one way or round trip. Travel can also include relatively short stays between successive movements.

The origin of the word "travel" is most likely lost to history. The term "travel" may originate from the Old French word travail, which means 'work'. According to the Merriam Webster dictionary, the first known use of the word travel was in the 14th century.

It also states that the word comes from Middle English travailen, travelen (which means to torment, labor, strive, journey) and earlier from Old French travailler (which means to work strenuously, toil). In English we still occasionally use the words "travail", which means struggle. According to Simon Winchester in his book The Best Travelers' Tales (2004), the words "travel" and "travail" both share an even more ancient root: a Roman instrument of torture called the tripalium (in Latin it means "three stakes", as in to impale).

";}s:9:"itinerary";a:3:{s:15:"itinerary_title";a:4:{i:1;s:39:"Arrival and Introduction to Paragliding";i:2;s:37:"First Flight and Paragliding Training";i:3;s:50:"Advanced Paragliding Experience and Scenic Flights";i:4;s:27:"Sunrise Flight and Farewell";}s:20:"itinerary_days_label";a:4:{i:1;s:6:"Day 01";i:2;s:6:"Day 02";i:3;s:6:"Day 03";i:4;s:6:"Day 04";}s:17:"itinerary_content";a:4:{i:1;s:593:"

Arrive at your destination, often a picturesque paragliding hub like Pokhara in Nepal, where the stunning views of the Himalayas set the stage for an exciting adventure. After checking into your hotel, you’ll meet your paragliding instructor for a briefing on the equipment, safety measures, and what to expect during the tour. The rest of the day is free to explore the town, soaking in the local culture, enjoying a lakeside stroll, or simply relaxing. In the evening, gather for a welcome dinner and get to know your fellow adventurers.

";i:2;s:636:"

After a hearty breakfast, head to the paragliding launch site, where you'll receive a safety briefing and a short training session. For those new to the sport, you'll have an opportunity for a tandem flight with an experienced instructor, gliding through the air and taking in breathtaking aerial views of mountains, lakes, and villages below. If you're already a seasoned paraglider, you can practice solo flights under the supervision of your instructor. Afterward, enjoy a relaxing afternoon, perhaps visiting local attractions like caves or temples, before a well-deserved dinner.

";i:3;s:620:"

Today, dive deeper into the sport with a series of more advanced flights. Depending on your skill level, you’ll have the opportunity to fly solo or tandem, navigating thermals and exploring new flight routes. Your instructor will guide you through the experience, teaching you the finer points of flight control, maneuvers, and landing techniques. The breathtaking landscapes of the surrounding mountains, valleys, and lakes will serve as the perfect backdrop. In the evening, enjoy a debriefing session to review your progress and discuss any areas for improvement.

";i:4;s:596:"

On your final day, rise early to catch a spectacular sunrise flight. Witness the sun lighting up the snow-capped peaks of the surrounding mountains as you soar high above the landscape. After your early morning adventure, enjoy a relaxed breakfast and a reflective session to share your experiences. The remainder of the day is yours to explore more of the local culture, shop for souvenirs, or simply relax by the lake before your departure. After an exhilarating few days, depart with unforgettable memories and a new passion for paragliding.

";}}s:4:"cost";a:4:{s:14:"includes_title";s:22:"The Trip Cost Includes";s:13:"cost_includes";s:704:"Pick-up or Drop-off service from and to Airport(in our own vehicle) Transportation to and from!! If you need any additional items such as gloves, jackets, or shoes, those can be rented or purchased locally.

item.title: Lake Kayaking
item.dc:creator: techteam
item.content:encoded:
The Annapurna Circuit is a trek within the Annapurna mountain range of central Nepal.The total length of the route varies between 160–230 km (100-145 mi), depending on where motor transportation is used and where the trek is ended. This trek crosses two different river valleys and encircles the Annapurna massif. The path reaches its highest point at Thorung La pass (5416m/17769 ft), touching the edge of the Tibetan plateau.

Practically all trekkers hike the route anticlockwise, as this way the daily altitude gain is slower, and crossing the high Thorong La pass is easier and safer. The mountain scenery, seen at close quarters includes the Annapurna Massif (Annapurna I-IV), Dhaulagiri, Machhapuchhre, Manaslu, Gangapurna, Tilicho Peak, Pisang Peak, and Paungda Danda. Numerous other peaks of 6000-8000m in elevation rise from the Annapurna range. The trek begins at Besisahar or Bhulbhule in the Marshyangdi river valley and concludes in the Kali Gandaki Gorge. Besisahar can be reached after a seven-hour drive from Kathmandu.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
a:7:{s:9:"trip_code";s:7:"WTE-270";s:13:"trip_duration";i:15;s:20:"trip_duration_nights";i:14;s:11:"tab_content";a:1:{s:10:"1_wpeditor";s:1268:"

Travel is the movement of people between relatively distant geographical locations, and can involve travel by foot, bicycle, automobile, train, boat, bus, airplane, or other means, with or without luggage, and can be one way or round trip. Travel can also include relatively short stays between successive movements.

The origin of the word "travel" is most likely lost to history. The term "travel" may originate from the Old French word travail, which means 'work'. According to the Merriam Webster dictionary, the first known use of the word travel was in the 14th century.

It also states that the word comes from Middle English travailen, travelen (which means to torment, labor, strive, journey) and earlier from Old French travailler (which means to work strenuously, toil). In English we still occasionally use the words "travail", which means struggle. According to Simon Winchester in his book The Best Travelers' Tales (2004), the words "travel" and "travail" both share an even more ancient root: a Roman instrument of torture called the tripalium (in Latin it means "three stakes", as in to impale).

";}s:9:"itinerary";a:3:{s:15:"itinerary_title";a:4:{i:1;s:41:"Arrival and Introduction to Lake Kayaking";i:2;s:29:"Kayak Basics and First Paddle";i:3;s:34:"Exploration and Scenic Paddle Tour";i:4;s:32:"Kayaking Challenge and Departure";}s:20:"itinerary_days_label";a:4:{i:1;s:6:"Day 01";i:2;s:6:"Day 02";i:3;s:6:"Day 03";i:4;s:6:"Day 04";}s:17:"itinerary_content";a:4:{i:1;s:597:"

Arrive at the tour's starting point, often a picturesque lakeside town, where you’ll be welcomed by your guides. After settling into your accommodations, gather for an orientation session where you’ll learn about the kayaking equipment, safety measures, and the itinerary for the next few days. The afternoon is free to explore the area, perhaps taking a scenic walk around the lake or relaxing by the water. In the evening, enjoy a delicious welcome dinner while soaking in the serene surroundings and preparing for your kayaking adventure.

";i:2;s:693:"

After a hearty breakfast, begin your first day on the water. Your guides will provide a thorough introduction to kayaking, including basic techniques, paddling strokes, and safety tips. You’ll then embark on your first kayaking session, paddling across the calm, clear waters of the lake. Enjoy the peaceful atmosphere and take in the stunning scenery of surrounding mountains and forests. After your paddle, take a break to relax by the shore, enjoy a packed lunch, and learn about the local history and wildlife. The day concludes with an evening at leisure, perhaps exploring nearby lakeside trails or relaxing in a cozy lakeside café.

";i:3;s:708:"

Today, you’ll venture further out onto the lake, exploring more remote areas and hidden coves. Your guide will lead you on a scenic paddle tour, navigating through tranquil inlets and stopping at scenic viewpoints along the way. This day offers a chance to experience the natural beauty of the lake up close, with opportunities to spot local wildlife like birds, fish, and other water creatures. You’ll also have the chance to practice your kayaking skills, learning more advanced strokes and techniques as you become more comfortable on the water. Afterward, enjoy a lakeside dinner, reflecting on your adventure and the beauty of the day’s journey.

";i:4;s:689:"

On your final day, take on a kayaking challenge, paddling to a more distant part of the lake or through more challenging water conditions. This will test your newly acquired skills and offer a rewarding sense of accomplishment. Your guides will ensure you’re prepared for the challenge, providing expert tips and support throughout the paddle. After the challenge, enjoy a leisurely paddle back to the starting point, where you’ll have time to relax and take in the view before preparing for departure. In the afternoon, you’ll have a final group reflection session and a farewell lunch, marking the end of your kayaking adventure.

";}}s:4:"cost";a:4:{s:14:"includes_title";s:22:"The Trip Cost Includes";s:13:"cost_includes";s:704:"Pick-up or Drop-off service from and to Airport(in our own vehicle) Transportation to and from!! Food all along the trip(Breakfast, Lunch, Dinner and a cup of coffee or tea) and accommodations during the trip in hotels with family environment Transportation, food, accommodation and insurance of Guide during the trip Down jacket, all-season sleeping bag, duffel bag and trekking map(in case if you don’t have your own. Down jacket, sleeping bag and duffel bag must be returned after completion of the trip) First Aid Medical Kit(Your guide will carry the Medical Kit but we also advise to bring yourself for your own use, as far as possible) All the required permits and paperwork";s:14:"excludes_title";s:22:"The Trip Cost Excludes";s:13:"cost_excludes";s:417:"International Airfare Visa Charges Hotel Expenses(In Kathmandu, some packages do include hotel expenses) Your travel and medical insurance Personal Expenses such as shopping, bar bills, hot shower, telephone, laundry, titbits etc Food and accommodations in Kathmandu Services not mentioned or not promised by the agent/agency Emergency expenses such as expenses on chartered helicopter.";}s:3:"faq";a:2:{s:9:"faq_title";a:4:{i:0;s:60:"What is the skill level required for the Lake Kayaking tour?";i:1;s:48:"How is safety managed during the kayaking tours?";i:2;s:40:"Do I need to bring my own kayaking gear?";i:3;s:69:"What is the group size, and how will we be supported during the tour?";}s:11:"faq_content";a:4:{i:0;s:489:"

The Lake Kayaking tour is suitable for all skill levels, from beginners to more experienced kayakers. On the first day, a comprehensive briefing and basic paddling lessons are provided, ensuring everyone is comfortable with the equipment and techniques. If you're new to kayaking, you'll start with easy, calm waters, while more experienced paddlers can take on longer distances or explore more challenging routes as the tour progresses.

";i:1;s:519:"

Safety is a top priority throughout the tour. All participants are provided with high-quality safety equipment, including life jackets, helmets, and paddles. Experienced guides lead all kayaking excursions, offering instructions on proper paddling techniques, water safety, and navigation. The guides continuously monitor weather conditions, ensuring paddling is done in safe, calm waters. In case of any issues, guides are trained in first aid and rescue procedures.

";i:2;s:413:"

No, all necessary kayaking equipment is provided for the duration of the tour, including kayaks, paddles, life jackets, and helmets. If you have your own gear, you're welcome to bring it, but it must meet safety standards. Participants should bring personal items such as water shoes, appropriate clothing for kayaking, sunscreen, and any necessary medications.

";i:3;s:530:"

Group sizes typically range from 6 to 12 participants, ensuring an intimate experience with personal attention from the guides. The tour includes full support, with guides managing logistics, providing instructions, and ensuring safety. Additionally, there are local staff available to assist with equipment, transportation, and any other needs. The group dynamic allows for a relaxed, social atmosphere while ensuring everyone receives expert guidance and support on the water.

";}}}

Food all along the trip(Breakfast, Lunch, Dinner and a cup of coffee or tea) and accommodations during the trip in hotels with family environment Transportation, food, accommodation and insurance of Guide during the trip Down jacket, all-season sleeping bag, duffel bag and trekking map(in case if you don’t have your own. Down jacket, sleeping bag and duffel bag must be returned after completion of the trip) First Aid Medical Kit(Your guide will carry the Medical Kit but we also advise to bring yourself for your own use, as far as possible) All the required permits and paperwork";s:14:"excludes_title";s:22:"The Trip Cost Excludes";s:13:"cost_excludes";s:417:"International Airfare Visa Charges Hotel Expenses(In Kathmandu, some packages do include hotel expenses) Your travel and medical insurance Personal Expenses such as shopping, bar bills, hot shower, telephone, laundry, titbits etc Food and accommodations in Kathmandu Services not mentioned or not promised by the agent/agency Emergency expenses such as expenses on chartered helicopter.";}s:3:"faq";a:2:{s:9:"faq_title";a:4:{i:0;s:60:"What is the skill level required for the Lake Kayaking tour?";i:1;s:48:"How is safety managed during the kayaking tours?";i:2;s:40:"Do I need to bring my own kayaking gear?";i:3;s:69:"What is the group size, and how will we be supported during the tour?";}s:11:"faq_content";a:4:{i:0;s:489:"

The Lake Kayaking tour is suitable for all skill levels, from beginners to more experienced kayakers. On the first day, a comprehensive briefing and basic paddling lessons are provided, ensuring everyone is comfortable with the equipment and techniques. If you're new to kayaking, you'll start with easy, calm waters, while more experienced paddlers can take on longer distances or explore more challenging routes as the tour progresses.

";i:1;s:519:"

Safety is a top priority throughout the tour. All participants are provided with high-quality safety equipment, including life jackets, helmets, and paddles. Experienced guides lead all kayaking excursions, offering instructions on proper paddling techniques, water safety, and navigation. The guides continuously monitor weather conditions, ensuring paddling is done in safe, calm waters. In case of any issues, guides are trained in first aid and rescue procedures.

";i:2;s:413:"

No, all necessary kayaking equipment is provided for the duration of the tour, including kayaks, paddles, life jackets, and helmets. If you have your own gear, you're welcome to bring it, but it must meet safety standards. Participants should bring personal items such as water shoes, appropriate clothing for kayaking, sunscreen, and any necessary medications.

";i:3;s:530:"

Group sizes typically range from 6 to 12 participants, ensuring an intimate experience with personal attention from the guides. The tour includes full support, with guides managing logistics, providing instructions, and ensuring safety. Additionally, there are local staff available to assist with equipment, transportation, and any other needs. The group dynamic allows for a relaxed, social atmosphere while ensuring everyone receives expert guidance and support on the water.

";}}}

a:7:{s:9:"trip_code";s:7:"WTE-270";s:13:"trip_duration";i:15;s:20:"trip_duration_nights";i:14;s:11:"tab_content";a:1:{s:10:"1_wpeditor";s:1268:"

Travel is the movement of people between relatively distant geographical locations, and can involve travel by foot, bicycle, automobile, train, boat, bus, airplane, or other means, with or without luggage, and can be one way or round trip. Travel can also include relatively short stays between successive movements.

The origin of the word "travel" is most likely lost to history. The term "travel" may originate from the Old French word travail, which means 'work'. According to the Merriam Webster dictionary, the first known use of the word travel was in the 14th century.

It also states that the word comes from Middle English travailen, travelen (which means to torment, labor, strive, journey) and earlier from Old French travailler (which means to work strenuously, toil). In English we still occasionally use the words "travail", which means struggle. According to Simon Winchester in his book The Best Travelers' Tales (2004), the words "travel" and "travail" both share an even more ancient root: a Roman instrument of torture called the tripalium (in Latin it means "three stakes", as in to impale).

";}s:9:"itinerary";a:3:{s:15:"itinerary_title";a:4:{i:1;s:41:"Arrival and Introduction to Lake Kayaking";i:2;s:29:"Kayak Basics and First Paddle";i:3;s:34:"Exploration and Scenic Paddle Tour";i:4;s:32:"Kayaking Challenge and Departure";}s:20:"itinerary_days_label";a:4:{i:1;s:6:"Day 01";i:2;s:6:"Day 02";i:3;s:6:"Day 03";i:4;s:6:"Day 04";}s:17:"itinerary_content";a:4:{i:1;s:597:"

Arrive at the tour's starting point, often a picturesque lakeside town, where you’ll be welcomed by your guides. After settling into your accommodations, gather for an orientation session where you’ll learn about the kayaking equipment, safety measures, and the itinerary for the next few days. The afternoon is free to explore the area, perhaps taking a scenic walk around the lake or relaxing by the water. In the evening, enjoy a delicious welcome dinner while soaking in the serene surroundings and preparing for your kayaking adventure.

";i:2;s:693:"

After a hearty breakfast, begin your first day on the water. Your guides will provide a thorough introduction to kayaking, including basic techniques, paddling strokes, and safety tips. You’ll then embark on your first kayaking session, paddling across the calm, clear waters of the lake. Enjoy the peaceful atmosphere and take in the stunning scenery of surrounding mountains and forests. After your paddle, take a break to relax by the shore, enjoy a packed lunch, and learn about the local history and wildlife. The day concludes with an evening at leisure, perhaps exploring nearby lakeside trails or relaxing in a cozy lakeside café.

";i:3;s:708:"

Today, you’ll venture further out onto the lake, exploring more remote areas and hidden coves. Your guide will lead you on a scenic paddle tour, navigating through tranquil inlets and stopping at scenic viewpoints along the way. This day offers a chance to experience the natural beauty of the lake up close, with opportunities to spot local wildlife like birds, fish, and other water creatures. You’ll also have the chance to practice your kayaking skills, learning more advanced strokes and techniques as you become more comfortable on the water. Afterward, enjoy a lakeside dinner, reflecting on your adventure and the beauty of the day’s journey.

";i:4;s:689:"

On your final day, take on a kayaking challenge, paddling to a more distant part of the lake or through more challenging water conditions. This will test your newly acquired skills and offer a rewarding sense of accomplishment. Your guides will ensure you’re prepared for the challenge, providing expert tips and support throughout the paddle. After the challenge, enjoy a leisurely paddle back to the starting point, where you’ll have time to relax and take in the view before preparing for departure. In the afternoon, you’ll have a final group reflection session and a farewell lunch, marking the end of your kayaking adventure.

";}}s:4:"cost";a:4:{s:14:"includes_title";s:22:"The Trip Cost Includes";s:13:"cost_includes";s:704:"Pick-up or Drop-off service from and to Airport(in our own vehicle) Transportation to and from!! Down jacket, sleeping bag and duffel bag must be returned after completion of the trip) First Aid Medical Kit(Your guide will carry the Medical Kit but we also advise to bring yourself for your own use, as far as possible) All the required permits and paperwork";s:14:"excludes_title";s:22:"The Trip Cost Excludes";s:13:"cost_excludes";s:417:"International Airfare Visa Charges Hotel Expenses(In Kathmandu, some packages do include hotel expenses) Your travel and medical insurance Personal Expenses such as shopping, bar bills, hot shower, telephone, laundry, titbits etc Food and accommodations in Kathmandu Services not mentioned or not promised by the agent/agency Emergency expenses such as expenses on chartered helicopter.";}s:3:"faq";a:2:{s:9:"faq_title";a:4:{i:0;s:60:"What is the skill level required for the Lake Kayaking tour?";i:1;s:48:"How is safety managed during the kayaking tours?";i:2;s:40:"Do I need to bring my own kayaking gear?";i:3;s:69:"What is the group size, and how will we be supported during the tour?";}s:11:"faq_content";a:4:{i:0;s:489:"

";i:1;s:519:"

Safety is a top priority throughout the tour. All participants are provided with high-quality safety equipment, including life jackets, helmets, and paddles. Experienced guides lead all kayaking excursions, offering instructions on proper paddling techniques, water safety, and navigation. The guides continuously monitor weather conditions, ensuring paddling is done in safe, calm waters. In case of any issues, guides are trained in first aid and rescue procedures.

No, all necessary kayaking equipment is provided for the duration of the tour, including kayaks, paddles, life jackets, and helmets. If you have your own gear, you're welcome to bring it, but it must meet safety standards. Participants should bring personal items such as water shoes, appropriate clothing for kayaking, sunscreen, and any necessary medications.

Group sizes typically range from 6 to 12 participants, ensuring an intimate experience with personal attention from the guides. The tour includes full support, with guides managing logistics, providing instructions, and ensuring safety. Additionally, there are local staff available to assist with equipment, transportation, and any other needs. The group dynamic allows for a relaxed, social atmosphere while ensuring everyone receives expert guidance and support on the water.

item.title: Elephant Ride
item.dc:creator: techteam
item.content:encoded:
The Annapurna Circuit is a trek within the Annapurna mountain range of central Nepal.The total length of the route varies between 160–230 km (100-145 mi), depending on where motor transportation is used and where the trek is ended. This trek crosses two different river valleys and encircles the Annapurna massif. The path reaches its highest point at Thorung La pass (5416m/17769 ft), touching the edge of the Tibetan plateau.

Practically all trekkers hike the route anticlockwise, as this way the daily altitude gain is slower, and crossing the high Thorong La pass is easier and safer. The mountain scenery, seen at close quarters includes the Annapurna Massif (Annapurna I-IV), Dhaulagiri, Machhapuchhre, Manaslu, Gangapurna, Tilicho Peak, Pisang Peak, and Paungda Danda. Numerous other peaks of 6000-8000m in elevation rise from the Annapurna range. The trek begins at Besisahar or Bhulbhule in the Marshyangdi river valley and concludes in the Kali Gandaki Gorge. Besisahar can be reached after a seven-hour drive from Kathmandu.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value:
a:7:{s:9:"trip_code";s:7:"WTE-271";s:13:"trip_duration";i:15;s:20:"trip_duration_nights";i:14;s:11:"tab_content";a:1:{s:10:"1_wpeditor";s:1268:"

Travel is the movement of people between relatively distant geographical locations, and can involve travel by foot, bicycle, automobile, train, boat, bus, airplane, or other means, with or without luggage, and can be one way or round trip. Travel can also include relatively short stays between successive movements.

The origin of the word "travel" is most likely lost to history. The term "travel" may originate from the Old French word travail, which means 'work'. According to the Merriam Webster dictionary, the first known use of the word travel was in the 14th century.

It also states that the word comes from Middle English travailen, travelen (which means to torment, labor, strive, journey) and earlier from Old French travailler (which means to work strenuously, toil). In English we still occasionally use the words "travail", which means struggle. According to Simon Winchester in his book The Best Travelers' Tales (2004), the words "travel" and "travail" both share an even more ancient root: a Roman instrument of torture called the tripalium (in Latin it means "three stakes", as in to impale).

";}s:9:"itinerary";a:3:{s:15:"itinerary_title";a:4:{i:1;s:41:"Arrival and Introduction to Elephant Ride";i:2;s:36:"Elephant Ride through the Wilderness";i:3;s:35:"Jungle Safari and Wildlife Spotting";i:4;s:26:"Morning Ride and Departure";}s:20:"itinerary_days_label";a:4:{i:1;s:6:"Day 01";i:2;s:6:"Day 02";i:3;s:6:"Day 03";i:4;s:6:"Day 04";}s:17:"itinerary_content";a:4:{i:1;s:666:"

Arrive at the starting point of your adventure, often a wildlife-rich destination like Chitwan National Park in Nepal or a similar location known for elephant safaris. After settling into your lodge or resort, you’ll be introduced to the elephants and the local guides who will accompany you throughout the tour. Spend the afternoon learning about the elephants' history, care, and conservation efforts, with a chance to interact with the animals in a respectful and educational environment. Enjoy a traditional dinner, listening to stories of the local wildlife and culture, and prepare for the adventure ahead.

";i:2;s:704:"

After a hearty breakfast, embark on your first elephant ride, which will take you through the lush jungles or grasslands of the national park. As you sit atop the elephant, your guide will point out various wildlife species, including rhinos, deer, and a variety of bird species, giving you a unique perspective on the wilderness. The ride will be leisurely, allowing you to take in the stunning scenery and enjoy the tranquility of the surroundings. In the afternoon, visit a local village or take part in a cultural program to learn about the traditions and daily life of the indigenous people. Enjoy another delicious meal as the evening winds down.

";i:3;s:686:"

On day three, embark on a deeper jungle safari, either by elephant or jeep, depending on your preference. Spend the day exploring different areas of the park, focusing on wildlife spotting. Your elephant ride will take you through more remote areas, where you'll have the chance to see elephants, Bengal tigers, crocodiles, and more. The ride offers great photographic opportunities, and your guide will share insights into the ecosystem, the importance of conservation, and the animals' behaviors. After the safari, enjoy a relaxing afternoon at the lodge, perhaps taking a nature walk or attending a workshop on wildlife protection.

";i:4;s:601:"

On your final day, enjoy a serene morning ride through the park, taking in the beauty of the landscape and its inhabitants as the sun rises. This peaceful ride will offer one last opportunity to spot wildlife and connect with nature before returning to the lodge. Afterward, enjoy a farewell breakfast and share your favorite moments with fellow travelers. Depending on your departure time, you might have the chance to visit a nearby elephant breeding center or participate in a final cultural exchange before heading back to your next destination.

";}}s:4:"cost";a:4:{s:14:"includes_title";s:22:"The Trip Cost Includes";s:13:"cost_includes";s:704:"Pick-up or Drop-off service from and to Airport(in our own vehicle) Transportation to and from!! Food all along the trip(Breakfast, Lunch, Dinner and a cup of coffee or tea) and accommodations during the trip in hotels with family environment Transportation, food, accommodation and insurance of Guide during the trip Down jacket, all-season sleeping bag, duffel bag and trekking map(in case if you don’t have your own. Down jacket, sleeping bag and duffel bag must be returned after completion of the trip) First Aid Medical Kit(Your guide will carry the Medical Kit but we also advise to bring yourself for your own use, as far as possible) All the required permits and paperwork";s:14:"excludes_title";s:22:"The Trip Cost Excludes";s:13:"cost_excludes";s:417:"International Airfare Visa Charges Hotel Expenses(In Kathmandu, some packages do include hotel expenses) Your travel and medical insurance Personal Expenses such as shopping, bar bills, hot shower, telephone, laundry, titbits etc Food and accommodations in Kathmandu Services not mentioned or not promised by the agent/agency Emergency expenses such as expenses on chartered helicopter.";}s:3:"faq";a:2:{s:9:"faq_title";a:4:{i:0;s:61:"What is the best time of year to take the Elephant Ride tour?";i:1;s:43:"Is the Elephant Ride safe for participants?";i:2;s:46:"What should I wear for the Elephant Ride tour?";i:3;s:46:"How long does the Elephant Ride last each day?";}s:11:"faq_content";a:4:{i:0;s:544:"

The best time to take the Elephant Ride tour is during the dry season, which typically runs from October to March. During this time, wildlife is more easily spotted as animals gather around water sources. The weather is also more comfortable for outdoor activities, with mild temperatures and clear skies. The wet season (June to September) can make travel more challenging due to rain, but it can also offer a lush, vibrant landscape for those who prefer a quieter, more secluded experience.

";i:1;s:540:"

Yes, the Elephant Ride is designed to be safe for all participants. The elephants used in the rides are well-trained and familiar with the route. The rides are accompanied by experienced mahouts (elephant drivers) who have a deep understanding of the animals and their behavior. Additionally, safety equipment such as secure seating and proper instructions are provided to ensure a comfortable and safe experience. Guides are trained in first aid and are always ready to assist if needed.

";i:2;s:467:"

It’s recommended to wear comfortable, light clothing suitable for outdoor activities. Long pants are advised for protection from the sun and possible insects. A hat and sunglasses are also recommended for sun protection. For footwear, sturdy shoes or sandals with good grip are ideal since the terrain can be uneven. It's also a good idea to bring insect repellent and sunscreen to ensure comfort during the ride.

";i:3;s:446:"

Each elephant ride typically lasts around 1.5 to 2 hours, depending on the itinerary and the location. The ride is usually conducted in the morning or late afternoon to avoid the heat of the midday sun, providing the best opportunity to observe wildlife. There may also be additional activities, such as cultural visits, jungle walks, or safari jeep tours, which may extend the day's adventure.

";}}}
